occurrences.line_text: Eftsoones vnto an holy Hospitall,
Withouten sword or shield, an host to quaile?
Gathering againe, her Host she did renew,
Her Host two hundred thousand numbred is;
Malbecco will no straunge knights host,
Maulgre his host, who grudged grieuously,
Three such as able were to match a puissant host.
Such was that Hag, vnmeet to host such guests,
For he their host them goodly well did cheare,
Which when their Host perceiu'd, right discontent
Ne would I gladly combate with mine host,
Whom when her Host saw readie to depart,
Gan greatly thanke his host and his good wife;
And an huge hoste into Northumber lead,
Yet secretly their hoste did on them lowre,
That his vngentle hoste n'ote him appeach
That none can there arriue without an hoste:
Sometimes great hostes of men she could dismay,
Huge hostes of men he could alone dismay,
And hostes of men of meanest things could frame,
Ne hostes of men with banners brode dispred,
Great hostes of men in order martiall,
Calidore hostes with Meliboe
But that accursed Hag, her hostesse late,
Forth ryding from Malbeccoes hostlesse hous,
Yeeld me an hostry mongst the croking frogs,
Hurled his beame so scorching cruell hot,
In prime of youthly yeares, when corage hot
When his hot ryder spurd his chauffed side;
Defyld those sacred waues, it rightly hot
Spurring so hote with rage dispiteous,
And after him another Knight, that hote
The hot-spurre youth so scorning to be crost,
Astond he stood, and vp his haire did houe,
Which houed close vnder a forrest side,
But darkenesse dred and daily night did houer
That with his seruant Trompart houerd there,
Like to a storme, which houers vnder skie
A little boate lay houing her before,
The combat, which he with Sansioy did hould;
And with long siege vs in this castle hould:
And often to him calling, to take surer hould.
Some fearing shriekt, some being harmed hould,
Who in his hand an yron flale did hould,
Deuize how to enlarge him out of hould.
Who through stro[n]g powre had now her self in hould,
And plucke the pray oftimes out of their greedy hould.
Tooke surer hould, and from his horses backe
And scorching flames of fierce Orions hound,
That no'te without an hound fine footing trace.
That shall I shew (said he) as sure, as hound
His crest was couered with a couchant Hound,
Did leape to her, as doth an eger hound
But he like hound full greedy of his pray,
And eke his steedes like to an hungry hound,
Quite topside turuey, and the pagan hound
And hidden wayes, that scarse an hound by smell
Came to her creeping like a fawning hound,
Is bayted of a mastiffe, and a hound,
Thinking to take them from that hylding hound:
Of hunter swift, and sent of houndes trew.
Some like to hounds, some like to Apes, dismayd,
Each hour did seeme a moneth, & euery moneth a yeare.
And for her Dwarfe, that wont to wait each houre;
In euill houre thy foes thee hither sent,
Whe[n] houre of death is come, let none aske whence, nor why.
They wist their houre was spe[n]t; the[n] each to rest him hyes.
For sith the houre, that first he did them let
From the fourth houre of night vntill the sixt;
That euery houre they knocke at deathes gate?
But ah vnhappy houre me thither brought:
Whose like they neuer saw till that same houre:
Vnto this houre, this present lucklesse howre,
Brought in vntimely houre, ere it was sought.
The morrow next, so soone as dawning houre
The saluage man, that neuer till this houre
Perdie (said he) in euill houre it fell,
From malicing, or grudging his good houre,
Looking each houre into deathes mouth to fall,
And wast thy ioyous houres in needlesse paine,
And in Amours the passing houres to spend,
Do rather choose my flitting houres to spend,
Which by the houres he measured, besought
But thought it all one night, that did no houres diuide.
Some blisfull houres at last must needes appeare;
For houres but dayes; for weekes, that passed were,
To heare so often, in that royall hous,
To light their blessed lamps in Ioues eternall hous.
Thy dwelling is, in Herebus blacke hous,
Him for to seeke, she left her heauenly hous,
Forth ryding from Malbeccoes hostlesse hous,
And all the people in that ample hous
For sooth he was descended of the hous
Arriued there, the little house they fill,
To Morpheus house doth hastily repaire.
Are you in this misformed house to dwell?
Vnto this house he brought, and did bestow
To sinfull house of Pride, Duessa
The house of mightie Prince it seemd to bee:
To Ioues high house through heauens bras-paued way
That shyning lampes in Ioues high house were light:
Or that great house of Gods cï¿½lestiall,
And downe to Plutoes house are come biliue:
The house of endlesse paine is built thereby,
The dreadfull spectacle of that sad house of Pride.
She fownd not in that perilous house of Pryde,
That to the house of heauenly gods it raught,
The house of Pride, and perils round about;
Then gan he lowdly through the house to call:
to house of Holinesse,
There was an auntient house not farre away,
In that sad house of Penaunce, where his spright
Of all the house had charge and gouernement,
To that most glorious house, that glistreth bright
That all the house did sweat with great aray:
The house was raysd, and all that in did dwell;
Ne euer shall I rest in house nor hold,
Who first to rayse our house to honour did begin.
That did the house of Richesse from hell-mouth diuide.
Therefore his house is vnto his annext;
Did neuer in that house it selfe display,
In Mammons house, the Palmer, whom whyleare
The house of Temperance, in which
When oblique Saturne sate in the house of agonyes.
Did shrieke alowd, that through the house it rong,
And reach into the house, that beares the stile
Into the balefull house of endlesse night,
The house of goodly formes and faire aspects,
To house a guest, that would be needes obayd,
Assayes the house of Busyrane,
Brought thee from balefull house of Proserpine,
Throughout the house, that clapped euery dore,
Anon she gan perceiue the house to quake,
Such was her house within; but all without,
To the three fatall sisters house she went.
Scudamour comming to Cares house,
About the house, at sent of stranger guest:
Who hauing left that restlesse house of Care,
Like to the balefull house of lowest hell,
Should for the Gods in Proteus house be made;
That Proteus house they fild euen to the dore;
In Ioues eternall house, vnwist of wight,
And filled all the house with feare and great vprore.
The goodman of this house was Dolon hight,
And ioyous light the house of Ioue forsooke:
And foule Echidna, in the house of night;
Downe to the house of dole, his daies there to deplore.
Now comest thou to rob my house vnmand,
To leaue, till to her fathers house he had her brought.
Till to that Ladies fathers house he came;
Or house to hide his head from heauens spight,
Small was his house, and like a little cage,
The people of the house rose forth in great vprore.
Were housed therewithin, whom he enlargen might.
And housed is within her hollow brest,
That house-rome craues, yet would be loth t'assay
That houses forme within was rude and strong,
Their banket houses burne, their buildings race,
And spoyld their houses, and them selues did murder;
With them as housewife euer to abide,
The housling fire did kindle and prouide,
Ah my deare Sonne (quoth he) how should, alas,
And to him playnd, how that false winged boy,
How he may worke vnto her further smarts:
He then deuisde himselfe how to disguise;
Was afterward, I know not how, conuaid
O how great sorrow my sad soule assaid.
But how long time, said then the Elfin knight,
O how, said he, mote I that well out find,
Heard how in vaine Fradubio did lament,
To thinke how she through guilefull handeling,
O how can beautie maister the most strong,
How does he find in cruell hart to hate
She has forgot, how many a wofull stowre
How many mischieues should ensue his heedlesse hast.
Forecasting, how his foe he might annoy,
And greeu'd, to thinke how foe did him destroy,
Deuizing, how that doughtie turnament
He standes amazed, how he thence should fade.
(Quoth she) how euer now in garments gilt,
And how haue seene vnwares. Lo now I go with thee.
How mortgaging their liues to Couetise,
How can ye vengeance iust so long withhold,
How faire he was, and yet not faire to this,
And how he slew with glauncing dart amisse
The Lyon whelpes she saw how he did beare,
How to escape. At last in priuie wise
How with that pensiue Maid he best might thence arise.
Ah dearest Lord (quoth she) how might that bee,
Ah dearest dame (quoth he) how might I see
How I him lou'd, and loue with all my might,
Ay me, how many perils doe enfold
How shall I quite the paines, ye suffer for my sake?
O heare, how piteous he to you for ayd does call.
How he did fashion his vntoward pace,
How ill it sits with that same siluer hed
How to aduaunce with fauourable hands,
How may a man (said he) with idle speach
And taught him how to take assured hold
How euer now accompted Elfins sonne,
How dare I thinke such glory to attaine?
O holy Sire (quoth he) how shall I quight
Ne wist yet, how his talants to vnfold;
To tell, how he had seene the Dragons fatall fall.
How can I tell, but that his talants may
To proue how many acres he did spread of land.
He nought forgot, how he whilome had sworne,
And dayly how through hardy enterprize,
To weete what course he takes, and how he fares;
Deare Lady how shall I declare thy cace,
How may it be, (said then the knight halfe wroth,)
How shamefully that Maid he did torment.
Certes (saide she) I wote not how he hight,
How that same knight should do so foule amis,
How that my Lord from her I would repriue,
To shew how sore bloudguiltinesse he hat'th;
He is conuaide, but how or where, here fits not tell.
And fairely fare on foot, how euer loth;
How in that place straunge knight arriued late,
How shall fraile pen descriue her heauenly face,
How they within their fouldings close enwrapped bee.
Not caring how, her silly life to saue,
So shakes off shame, ne thinks how erst she did her hide.
And told for secret how he vnderstood
Confest, how Philemon her wrought to chaunge her weede.
But read how art thou nam'd, and of what kin.
How hight he then (said Guyon) and from whence?
Ne care, ne feare I, how the wind do blow,
How they themselues doe thine ensample make,
Out of her fruitfull lap; how, no man knowes,
Loe loe how braue she decks her bounteous boure,
Gan him auize, how ill did him beseeme,
Loe, loe alreadie, how the fowles in aire
Ah well away, most noble Lords, how can
How without stop or stay he fiercely lept,
O how I burne with implacable fire,
But would they thinke, with how small allowaunce
To teach them how to vse their present state.
How oft do they, their siluer bowers leaue,
How oft do they with golden pineons, cleaue
How euer, sure I rew his pitteous plight.
How that thou art partaker of his crime:
Traytour what hast thou doen? how euer may
How that straunge sword refusd, to serue his need,
O how great wonder would your thoughts deuoure,
How may straunge knight hope euer to aspire,
And knew them how to order without blame,
How is it, that this mood in me ye blame,
Did sit, as yet ashamd, how rude Pan did her dight.
And counselled faire Alma, how to gouerne well.
How shall fraile pen, with feare disparaged,
But whence they sprong, or how they were begot,
And taught her first how to be conquered;
How oft that day did sad Brunchildis see
Cryde out, Deare countrey, Ã´ how dearely deare
How brutish is it not to vnderstand,
How much to her we owe, that all vs gaue,
It told, how first Prometheus did create
That how the time was fled, they quite forgate,
To thinke, how supper did them long awaite.
How to take life from that dead-liuing swaine,
How th'Earth his mother was, and first him bore;
How to direct their way in darkenesse wide,
Ah see the Virgin Rose, how sweetly shee
Lo see soone after, how more bold and free
Loe see soone after, how she fades, and falles away.
How then shall I, Apprentice of the skill,
How euer finely she it faind to hide:
And thus replide, How euer, Sir, ye file
Where now on earth, or how he may be found;
How euer list her now her knowledge faine,
She woxe; yet wist she neither how, nor why,
Aye me, how much I feare, least loue it bee;
For they, how euer shamefull and vnkind,
She wist not how t'amend, nor how it to withstond.
She wist not how t'amend, nor how it to withstond.
How shall she know, how shall she find the man?
How shall she know, how shall she find the man?
How like a Gyaunt in each manly part
How to effect so hard an enterprize,
Ah read, (quoth Britomart) how is she hight?
But when I read, how stout Debora strake
Proud Sisera, and how Camill' hath slaine
How can they other do, sith both are bold and blind?
How diuersly loue doth his pageants play,
What mister wight (said he) and how arayd?
But can ye read Sir, how I may her find, or where.
And vnto them complained, how that he
How that a noble hunteresse did wonne,
How him in deadly case their Lady fownd,
How then? of all loue taketh equall vew:
Ye wonder, how this noble Damozell
Conceiu'd these infants, and how them she bare,
Complayning, how with his empoysned shot
How he their heedlesse harts with loue had fyred,
She sweetly heard complaine, both how and what
He wist not, how him to despoile of life,
Ne how to win the wished victory,
And how he fell into that Gyaunts hands,
Did aske me, how I could her loue deserue,
And how she might be sure, that I would neuer swerue.
How many foundst thou such to put in thy record?
To thinke, how causelesse of her owne accord
How she might heale her sonne, whose senses were decayd.
Ne how to speake, ne how to vse his gest,
Ne how to speake, ne how to vse his gest,
Tho rudely askt her, how she thither came.
How soone would yee assemble many a fleete,
See how the heauens of voluntary grace,
Then said, Faire Sir, how may I weene it trew,
For perdie else how mote it euer bee,
How to auenge himselfe so sore abusd,
Behold, Sir, how your pitifull complaint
To weet how he her loue away did steale,
Ne wist he how to turne, nor to what place;
But when he marked, how his money burnd,
Malbecco seeing, how his losse did lye,
He gan deuise, how her he reskew mought,
With purpose, how they might it best betray;
How suffrest thou such shamefull cruelty,
Ne in that stownd wist, how her selfe to beare;
And how we with our foe may come to fight.
Therein was writ, how often thundring Ioue
Ah, how the fearefull Ladies tender hart
How towards her he rusht, and smiled at his pryde.
Then shewd it, how the Thebane Semelee
How the rude Shepheards after him did stare,
How oft for Venus, and how often eek
How oft for Venus, and how often eek
More eath to number, with how many eyes
(Ah man beware, how thou those darts behold)
How ouer that same dore was likewise writ,
Cast how to salue, that both the custome showne
How she might ouerthrow the things that Concord wrought.
Yet mindfull how he late by one was feld,
Ah gentle knights (quoth he) how may that bee,
How euer gay and goodly be the style,
How may these rimes, so rude as doth appeare,
How to preuent the perill that mote rise,
Beholding how the thrids of life they span:
Or how their liues were eekt, she did not tell;
Well mote ye wonder how that noble Knight,
Else how could one of equall might with most,
How hauing reft her from the witches sonne,
He gan to cast how to appease the same,
In which poursuit how each one did succeede,
Well weeting how their errour to assoyle,
And how that Hag his loue abused had
How euer she her paynd with womanish art
And yeelded leaue, how euer malcontent
How he the name of one engrauen had,
Yet saw he often how he wexed glad,
When he it heard, and how the ground he kist,
Wherein it written was, and how himselfe he blist:
Them thether brought, and how their harmes befell.
And how from thraldome vile they were vntide
Where was her won, and how he mote her find.
How all the way the Prince on footpace traced,
Yet seeing not how thence he mote remoue,
And shew'd him how through error and mis-thought
Finding no meanes how I might vs enlarge,
He gan aduise how best he mote darrayne
And mazd how nature had so well disguized
Diuided them, how euer loth to rest,
And told at large how that same errant Knight,
Here neede you to remember, how erewhile
How can they all in this so narrow verse
How from that dungeon he might her enlarge:
He wist not how her thence away to bere;
How she that Ladies libertie might enterprize.
How she was found againe, and spousde to Marinell.
What mister wight (quoth he) and how far hence
How he mis-led the simple peoples traine,
And looke then how much it doth ouerflow,
Seest not, how badly all things present bee,
And th'earth it selfe how daily its increast,
Of things vnseene how canst thou deeme aright,
How euer gay their blossome or their blade
For how canst thou those greater secrets know,
And gan inquire, how was that steed bereaued,
To thinke with how great vaunt of brauerie
But see how much her purpose was deceaued.
Your misery, how fell ye in this state.
How hight that Amazon (sayd Artegall?)
And where, and how far hence does she abide?
How Fortune will your ruin'd name repaire,
How that three warlike persons did appeare,
Wayting, how Fortune would resolue that daungerous dout.
How for Iolas sake he did apply
How euer it his noble heart did gall,
Therefore I cast, how I may him vnbind,
To thinke how this long death thou mightest disinherit.
How earnest suit she earst for him had made
Deuize how to enlarge him out of hould.
But rather how she mote him faster tye.
And where is he thy Lord, and how far hence?
How to reuenge that blot of honour blent;
Who well perceiuing, how her wand she shooke,
How coul[d]st thou weene, through that disguized hood,
How euer loth he were his way to slake,
How worthily, by heauens high decree,
A dreadfull depth, how deepe no man can tell;
How he his nets doth for their ruine lay:
First gan he tell, how this that seem'd so faire
And with them practiz'd, how for to depryue
How that the Lady Belge now had found
And watch aduauntage, how to worke his care:
How cleare I am from blame of this vpbraide:
But now aread, Sir Sergis, how long space,
And forced them, how euer strong and stout
His studie was true Iustice how to deale,
How to reforme that ragged common-weale:
How to depraue, or slaunderously vpbrayd,
How they might make him into mischiefe fall,
Or good direction, how to enter in,
Or how to issue forth in waies vntryde,
Yet know I not or how, or in what place
Lying in waite, how him he damadge might.
And tryde all waies, how each mote entrance make
How euer strong and fortunate in fight,
How can he mercy euer hope to haue?
He vp arose, how euer liefe or loth,
Sonne of a King, how euer thorough fate
In which she shew'd, how that discourteous knight
What manner wight he was, and how yclad,
And how ye may him hence, and to what part
How thence she might conuay him to some place.
How great a hazard she at earst had made
How she the blame might salue with coloured disguize.
How to saue hole her hazarded estate;
But yet aread to me, how hight thy Lord,
Then Calepine, how euer inly wroth,
His foe t'assayle, or how himselfe to gard,
Lo how good fortune doth to you present
The gentle bloud, how euer it be wrapt
How euer by hard hap he hether came;
Whenas these Knights arriu'd, they wist not where nor how.
How each to entertaine with curt'sie well beseene,
And how thereof her selfe she did acquite,
Who hearing how his people badly sped,
And how to please the minds of good and ill,
Yet thus at length he said, How now Sir Knight?
How fortuneth this foule vncomely plight,
How both he and his fellow there in place
And how that he in lieu of life him lent,
How euer they through treason doe trespasse.
Aie me, how could her loue make half amends therefore.
Be well aware, how ye the same doe vse,
See how they doe that Squire beat and reuile;
See how they doe the Lady hale and draw.
How much (sayd he) more happie is the state,
Or from the Goat her kidde how to conuay;
He mindeth more, how he may be relieued
Looke how the Crowne, which Ariadne wore
They teach vs, how to each degree and kynde
To whom they shewed, how those marchants were
So shew'd them her, to proue how pale & weake she was.
Ne ought would buy, how euer prisd with measure,
For that same mayd, how euer it him greeues,
How many of their friends were slaine, how many fone.
How many of their friends were slaine, how many fone.
How could the death dare euer her to quell?
This wofull tale? or how those Brigants vyle,
Or how faire Pastorell should haue bene sold
Or how those theeues, whilest one sought her to hold,
How he might saue her life, if life did last;
Or if that dead, how he her death might wreake,
In hope there newes to learne, how they mote best assay.
How many flyes in whottest sommers day
Asham'd to thinke, how he that enterprize,
To tell her, how the heauens had her graste,
Askt her, how mote her words be vnderstood,
And gan to question streight how she it knew.
Howbe that carefull Hermite did his best,
And Howell Dha shall goodly well indew
And with his axe him smote in euill hower,
And howld aloud to see his Lord there slaine,
And hungry Wolues continually did howle,
And all about it wandring ghostes did waile and howle.
And all the night the dogs did barke and howle
With hollow howling, and lamenting cry,
The wretched woman, whom vnhappy howre
Of all her passed paines: one louing howre
Of deare Sansfoy, I neuer ioyed howre,
That God to vs forgiueth euery howre
Or earthly wight thou be, withhold this deadly howre.
He promised to bring me at that howre,
And now by this, Cymochles howre was spent,
For now arriued is his fatall howre,
Nath'lesse the same enioyed but short happy howre:
Fairer and nobler liueth none this howre,
Faire Sir, I let you weete, that from the howre
But better fortune thine, and better howre,
For gold, or perles, or pretious stones an howre,
The which Rinaldo drunck in happie howre,
On Acidalian mount, where many an howre
Vpon them fell, before her timely howre;
The morrow next about the wonted howre,
Vnto this houre, this present lucklesse howre,
I neuer ioyed howre, but still with care was moued.
